an8.35:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these eight rebirths by giving.

an8.35:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco dānaṃ deti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an8.35:1.3.eng: First, someone gives to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

an8.35:1.4.eng: Whatever they give they expect back.

an8.35:1.5.pli: So passati khattiyamahāsāle vā brāhmaṇamahāsāle vā gahapatimahāsāle vā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappite samaṅgībhūte paricārayamāne.
an8.35:1.5.eng: They see a well-to-do aristocrat or brahmin or householder amusing themselves, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

an8.35:1.7.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā khattiyamahāsālānaṃ vā brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṃ vā gahapatimahāsālānaṃ vā sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
an8.35:1.7.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders!’

an8.35:1.8.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
an8.35:1.8.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.

an8.35:1.9.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ hīne vimuttaṃ, uttari abhāvitaṃ, tatrūpapattiyā saṃvattati.
an8.35:1.9.eng: As they’ve settled for less and not developed further, their thought leads to rebirth there.

an8.35:1.10.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā khattiyamahāsālānaṃ vā brāhmaṇamahāsālānaṃ vā gahapatimahāsālānaṃ vā sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.35:1.10.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of well-to-do aristocrats or brahmins or householders.

an8.35:1.11.pli: Tañca kho sīlavato vadāmi, no dussīlassa.
an8.35:1.11.eng: But I say that this is only for those of ethical conduct, not for the unethical.

an8.35:1.12.eng: The heart’s wish of an ethical person succeeds because of their purity.

an8.35:2.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco dānaṃ deti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an8.35:2.1.eng: Next, someone gives to ascetics or brahmins …

an8.35:2.2.eng: Whatever they give they expect back.

an8.35:2.4.eng: ‘The gods of the four great kings are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

an8.35:2.6.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
an8.35:2.6.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the four great kings!’ …

an8.35:2.7.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.

an8.35:2.8.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ hīne vimuttaṃ, uttari abhāvitaṃ, tatrūpapattiyā saṃvattati.

an8.35:2.9.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.35:2.9.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the four great kings.

an8.35:2.10.pli: Tañca kho sīlavato vadāmi, no dussīlassa.
an8.35:2.10.eng: But I say that this is only for those of ethical conduct, not for the unethical.

an8.35:2.11.eng: The heart’s wish of an ethical person succeeds because of their purity.

an8.35:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco dānaṃ deti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an8.35:3.1.eng: Next, someone gives to ascetics or brahmins …

an8.35:3.2.eng: Whatever they give they expect back.

an8.35:3.8.eng: ‘The gods who control what is created by others are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

an8.35:3.10.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
an8.35:3.10.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others!’

an8.35:3.11.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
an8.35:3.11.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.

an8.35:3.12.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ hīne vimuttaṃ, uttari abhāvitaṃ, tatrūpapattiyā saṃvattati.
an8.35:3.12.eng: As they’ve settled for less and not developed further, their thought leads to rebirth there.

an8.35:3.13.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.35:3.13.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others.

an8.35:3.14.pli: Tañca kho sīlavato vadāmi, no dussīlassa.
an8.35:3.14.eng: But I say that this is only for those of ethical conduct, not for the unethical.

an8.35:3.15.eng: The heart’s wish of an ethical person succeeds because of their purity.

an8.35:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekacco dānaṃ deti samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ yānaṃ mālāgandhavilepanaṃ seyyāvasathapadīpeyyaṃ.
an8.35:4.1.eng: Next, someone gives to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.

an8.35:4.2.eng: Whatever they give they expect back.

an8.35:4.4.eng: ‘The gods of the Divinity’s host are long-lived, beautiful, and very happy.’

an8.35:4.6.pli: ‘aho vatāhaṃ kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyyan’ti.
an8.35:4.6.eng: ‘If only, when my body breaks up, after death, I would be reborn in the company of the gods of the Divinity’s host!’

an8.35:4.7.pli: So taṃ cittaṃ dahati, taṃ cittaṃ adhiṭṭhāti, taṃ cittaṃ bhāveti.
an8.35:4.7.eng: They settle on that thought, stabilize it, and develop it.

an8.35:4.8.pli: Tassa taṃ cittaṃ hīne vimuttaṃ, uttari abhāvitaṃ, tatrūpapattiyā saṃvattati.
an8.35:4.8.eng: As they’ve settled for less and not developed further, their thought leads to rebirth there.

an8.35:4.9.pli: Kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā brahmakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.35:4.9.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the Divinity’s host.

an8.35:4.10.pli: Tañca kho sīlavato vadāmi, no dussīlassa;
an8.35:4.10.eng: But I say that this is only for those of ethical conduct, not for the unethical.

an8.35:4.11.eng: And for those free of desire, not those with desire.

an8.35:4.12.eng: The heart’s wish of an ethical person succeeds because of their freedom from desire.

an8.35:4.13.eng: These are the eight rebirths by giving.”

an8.36:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these three grounds for making merit.

an8.36:1.3.pli: Dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu.
an8.36:1.3.eng: Giving, ethical conduct, and meditation are all grounds for making merit.

an8.36:2.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu parittaṃ kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu parittaṃ kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:2.1.eng: First, someone has practiced a little giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:2.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manussadobhagyaṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:2.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn among disadvantaged humans.

an8.36:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu mattaso kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu mattaso kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:3.1.eng: Next, someone has practiced a moderate amount of giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:3.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manussasobhagyaṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:3.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn among well-off humans.

an8.36:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:4.1.eng: Next, someone has practiced to an extraordinary degree giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:4.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:4.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the four great kings.

an8.36:4.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, cattāro mahārājāno dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, cātumahārājike deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhanti—
an8.36:4.3.eng: There, the four great kings themselves have practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So they surpass them in ten respects:

an8.36:4.4.pli: dibbena āyunā, dibbena vaṇṇena, dibbena sukhena, dibbena yasena, dibbena ādhipateyyena, dibbehi rūpehi, dibbehi saddehi, dibbehi gandhehi, dibbehi rasehi, dibbehi phoṭṭhabbehi.
an8.36:4.4.eng: heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an8.36:5.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:5.1.eng: Next, someone has practiced to an extraordinary degree giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:5.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tāvatiṃsānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:5.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the thirty-three.

an8.36:5.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā tāvatiṃse deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an8.36:5.3.eng: There, Sakka, lord of gods, has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …

an8.36:6.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:6.1.eng: Next, someone has practiced to an extraordinary degree giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:6.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā yāmānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:6.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of Yama.

an8.36:6.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, suyāmo devaputto dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, yāme deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an8.36:6.3.eng: There, the godling Suyāma has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …

an8.36:7.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:7.1.eng: Next, someone has practiced to an extraordinary degree giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:7.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā tusitānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:7.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the joyful gods.

an8.36:7.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, santusito devaputto dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, tusite deve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an8.36:7.3.eng: There, the godling Santusita has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …

an8.36:8.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:8.1.eng: Next, someone has practiced to an extraordinary degree giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:8.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā nimmānaratīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:8.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods who love to create.

an8.36:8.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, sunimmito devaputto dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, nimmānaratīdeve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an8.36:8.3.eng: There, the godling Sunimmita has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects …

an8.36:9.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, ekaccassa dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthu adhimattaṃ kataṃ hoti, bhāvanāmayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ nābhisambhoti.
an8.36:9.1.eng: Next, someone has practiced to an extraordinary degree giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit, but they haven’t got as far as meditation as a ground for making merit.

an8.36:9.2.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.36:9.2.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others.

an8.36:9.3.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, vasavattī devaputto dānamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, sīlamayaṃ puññakiriyavatthuṃ atirekaṃ karitvā, paranimmitavasavattīdeve dasahi ṭhānehi adhigaṇhāti—
an8.36:9.3.eng: There, the godling Vasavattī has practiced giving and ethical conduct as grounds for making merit to a greater degree than the other gods. So he surpasses them in ten respects:

an8.36:9.4.pli: dibbena āyunā, dibbena vaṇṇena, dibbena sukhena, dibbena yasena, dibbena ādhipateyyena, dibbehi rūpehi, dibbehi saddehi, dibbehi gandhehi, dibbehi rasehi, dibbehi phoṭṭhabbehi.
an8.36:9.4.eng: heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, sovereignty, sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

an8.36:9.5.eng: These are the three grounds for making merit.”

an8.37:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these eight gifts of a true person.

an8.37:1.3.pli: Suciṃ deti, paṇītaṃ deti, kālena deti, kappiyaṃ deti, viceyya deti, abhiṇhaṃ deti, dadaṃ cittaṃ pasādeti, datvā attamano hoti.
an8.37:1.3.eng: Their gift is pure, good quality, timely, appropriate, intelligent, and regular. While giving their heart is confident, and afterwards they’re uplifted.

an8.37:1.4.eng: These are the eight gifts of a true person.

an8.37:2.1.eng: He gives pure, good quality, and timely gifts

an8.37:2.4.eng: who are fertile fields of merit.

an8.37:3.2.eng: giving away many things of the flesh.

an8.37:4.1.eng: An intelligent person sacrifices like this,

an8.37:4.2.eng: faithful, with a mind of letting go.

an8.37:4.3.eng: Such an astute person is reborn

an8.38:1.1.pli: “Sappuriso, bhikkhave, kule jāyamāno bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti—
an8.38:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a true person is born in a family for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people.

an8.38:1.2.pli: mātāpitūnaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, puttadārassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, dāsakammakaraporisassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, mittāmaccānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, pubbapetānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, rañño atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, devatānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti.
an8.38:1.2.eng: For the benefit, welfare, and happiness of mother and father; children and partners; bondservants, workers, and staff; friends and colleagues; departed ancestors; the king; the deities; and ascetics and brahmins.

an8.38:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahāmegho sabbasassāni sampādento bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti;
an8.38:2.1.eng: It’s like a great rain cloud, which nourishes all the crops for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people.

an8.38:2.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sappuriso kule jāyamāno bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti—
an8.38:2.2.eng: In the same way, a true person is born in a family for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of the people. …

an8.38:2.3.pli: mātāpitūnaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, puttadārassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, dāsakammakaraporisassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, mittāmaccānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, pubbapetānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, rañño atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, devatānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hoti, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṃ atthāya hitāya sukhāya hotīti.

an8.38:3.1.eng: A wise person living at home

an8.38:3.3.eng: Neither by day or at night do they neglect

an8.38:4.1.eng: They venerate them in accord with the teaching,

an8.38:4.3.eng: One of settled faith and good nature

an8.38:5.3.eng: Good for the king, good for the gods,

an8.38:5.4.eng: and good for relatives and comrades.

an8.38:6.1.eng: In fact, they’re good for everyone,

an8.38:6.2.eng: well grounded in the true teaching.

an8.38:6.3.eng: Rid of the stain of stinginess,

an8.38:6.4.eng: they’ll enjoy a world of grace.”

an8.39:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā sovaggikā sukhavipākā saggasaṃvattanikā, iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattanti.
an8.39:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these eight kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.

an8.39:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti.
an8.39:1.3.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple has gone for refuge to the Buddha.

an8.39:1.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko, iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati.
an8.39:1.4.eng: This is the first kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti.
an8.39:2.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has gone for refuge to the teaching.

an8.39:2.2.eng: This is the second kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti.
an8.39:3.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple has gone for refuge to the Saṅgha.

an8.39:3.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko, iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati.
an8.39:3.2.eng: This is the third kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:3.3.pli: Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, dānāni mahādānāni aggaññāni rattaññāni vaṃsaññāni porāṇāni asaṅkiṇṇāni asaṅkiṇṇapubbāni, na saṅkiyanti na saṅkiyissanti, appaṭikuṭṭhāni samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an8.39:3.3.eng: Mendicants, these five gifts are great, primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. They are uncorrupted, as they have been since the beginning. They’re not being corrupted now nor will they be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on them.

an8.39:3.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti.
an8.39:3.5.eng: Firstly, a noble disciple gives up killing living creatures.

an8.39:3.6.pli: Pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ abhayaṃ deti, averaṃ deti, abyābajjhaṃ deti.
an8.39:3.6.eng: By so doing they give to countless sentient beings the gift of freedom from fear, enmity, and ill will.

an8.39:3.7.pli: Aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ abhayaṃ datvā averaṃ datvā abyābajjhaṃ datvā aparimāṇassa abhayassa averassa abyābajjhassa bhāgī hoti.
an8.39:3.7.eng: And they themselves also enjoy unlimited freedom from fear, enmity, and ill will.

an8.39:3.8.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamaṃ dānaṃ mahādānaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkiyati na saṅkiyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an8.39:3.8.eng: This is the first gift that is a great offering, primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. It is uncorrupted, as it has been since the beginning. It’s not being corrupted now nor will it be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on it.

an8.39:3.9.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko, iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati.
an8.39:3.9.eng: This is the fourth kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti
an8.39:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple gives up stealing. …

an8.39:4.2.eng: This is the fifth kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple gives up sexual misconduct. …

an8.39:5.2.eng: This is the sixth kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple gives up lying. …

an8.39:6.2.eng: This is the seventh kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:7.1.eng: Furthermore, a noble disciple gives up beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an8.39:7.2.pli: Surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ abhayaṃ deti averaṃ deti abyābajjhaṃ deti.
an8.39:7.2.eng: By so doing they give to countless sentient beings the gift of freedom from fear, enmity, and ill will.

an8.39:7.3.pli: Aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ abhayaṃ datvā averaṃ datvā abyābajjhaṃ datvā, aparimāṇassa abhayassa averassa abyābajjhassa bhāgī hoti.
an8.39:7.3.eng: And they themselves also enjoy unlimited freedom from fear, enmity, and ill will.

an8.39:7.4.pli: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamaṃ dānaṃ mahādānaṃ aggaññaṃ rattaññaṃ vaṃsaññaṃ porāṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇaṃ asaṅkiṇṇapubbaṃ, na saṅkiyati na saṅkiyissati, appaṭikuṭṭhaṃ samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi.
an8.39:7.4.eng: This is the fifth gift that is a great offering, primordial, long-standing, traditional, and ancient. It is uncorrupted, as it has been since the beginning. It’s not being corrupted now nor will it be. Sensible ascetics and brahmins don’t look down on it.

an8.39:7.5.pli: Ayaṃ kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhamo puññābhisando kusalābhisando sukhassāhāro sovaggiko sukhavipāko saggasaṃvattaniko, iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattati.
an8.39:7.5.eng: This is the eighth kind of overflowing merit …

an8.39:8.1.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭha puññābhisandā kusalābhisandā sukhassāhārā sovaggikā sukhavipākā saggasaṃvattanikā, iṭṭhāya kantāya manāpāya hitāya sukhāya saṃvattantī”ti.
an8.39:8.1.eng: These are the eight kinds of overflowing merit, overflowing goodness. They nurture happiness and are conducive to heaven, ripening in happiness and leading to heaven. They lead to what is likable, desirable, agreeable, to welfare and happiness.”

an8.4:1.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ appiyo ca hoti amanāpo ca agaru ca abhāvanīyo ca.
an8.4:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with eight qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.

an8.4:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu lābhakāmo ca hoti, sakkārakāmo ca, anavaññattikāmo ca, akālaññū ca, amattaññū ca, asuci ca, bahubhāṇī ca, akkosakaparibhāsako ca sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.4:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant desires material things, honor, and status. They know neither moderation nor the proper time. Their conduct is impure, they talk a lot, and they insult and abuse their spiritual companions.

an8.4:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ appiyo ca hoti amanāpo ca agaru ca abhāvanīyo ca.
an8.4:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is disliked and disapproved by their spiritual companions, not respected or admired.

an8.4:2.1.pli: Aṭṭhahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo ca.
an8.4:2.1.eng: A mendicant with eight qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, and respected and admired.

an8.4:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na lābhakāmo ca hoti, na sakkārakāmo ca, na anavaññattikāmo ca, kālaññū ca, mattaññū ca, suci ca, na bahubhāṇī ca, anakkosakaparibhāsako ca sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.4:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t desire material things, honor, and status. They know moderation and the proper time. Their conduct is pure, they don’t talk a lot, and they don’t insult and abuse their spiritual companions.

an8.4:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu sabrahmacārīnaṃ piyo ca hoti manāpo ca garu ca bhāvanīyo cā”ti.
an8.4:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these eight qualities is liked and approved by their spiritual companions, and respected and admired.”

an8.40:1.1.pli: “Pāṇātipāto, bhikkhave, āsevito bhāvito bahulīkato nirayasaṃvattaniko tiracchānayonisaṃvattaniko pettivisayasaṃvattaniko.
an8.40:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the killing of living creatures, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:1.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso pāṇātipātassa vipāko, manussabhūtassa appāyukasaṃvattaniko hoti.
an8.40:1.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is a short lifespan.

an8.40:2.1.pli: Adinnādānaṃ, bhikkhave, āsevitaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ nirayasaṃvattanikaṃ tiracchānayonisaṃvattanikaṃ pettivisayasaṃvattanikaṃ.
an8.40:2.1.eng: Stealing, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:2.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso adinnādānassa vipāko, manussabhūtassa bhogabyasanasaṃvattaniko hoti.
an8.40:2.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is loss of wealth.

an8.40:3.1.pli: Kāmesumicchācāro, bhikkhave, āsevito bhāvito bahulīkato nirayasaṃvattaniko tiracchānayonisaṃvattaniko pettivisayasaṃvattaniko.
an8.40:3.1.eng: Sexual misconduct, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:3.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso kāmesumicchācārassa vipāko, manussabhūtassa sapattaverasaṃvattaniko hoti.
an8.40:3.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is rivalry and enmity.

an8.40:4.1.pli: Musāvādo, bhikkhave, āsevito bhāvito bahulīkato nirayasaṃvattaniko tiracchānayonisaṃvattaniko pettivisayasaṃvattaniko.
an8.40:4.1.eng: Lying, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:4.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso musāvādassa vipāko, manussabhūtassa abhūtabbhakkhānasaṃvattaniko hoti.
an8.40:4.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is false accusations.

an8.40:5.1.pli: Pisuṇā, bhikkhave, vācā āsevitā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nirayasaṃvattanikā tiracchānayonisaṃvattanikā pettivisayasaṃvattanikā.
an8.40:5.1.eng: Divisive speech, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:5.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso pisuṇāya vācāya vipāko, manussabhūtassa mittehi bhedanasaṃvattaniko hoti.
an8.40:5.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is being divided against friends.

an8.40:6.1.pli: Pharusā, bhikkhave, vācā āsevitā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nirayasaṃvattanikā tiracchānayonisaṃvattanikā pettivisayasaṃvattanikā.
an8.40:6.1.eng: Harsh speech, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:6.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso pharusāya vācāya vipāko, manussabhūtassa amanāpasaddasaṃvattaniko hoti.
an8.40:6.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is hearing disagreeable things.

an8.40:7.1.pli: Samphappalāpo, bhikkhave, āsevito bhāvito bahulīkato nirayasaṃvattaniko tiracchānayonisaṃvattaniko pettivisayasaṃvattaniko.
an8.40:7.1.eng: Talking nonsense, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:7.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso samphappalāpassa vipāko, manussabhūtassa anādeyyavācāsaṃvattaniko hoti.
an8.40:7.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is that no-one takes what you say seriously.

an8.40:8.1.pli: Surāmerayapānaṃ, bhikkhave, āsevitaṃ bhāvitaṃ bahulīkataṃ nirayasaṃvattanikaṃ tiracchānayonisaṃvattanikaṃ pettivisayasaṃvattanikaṃ.
an8.40:8.1.eng: Drinking beer and wine, when cultivated, developed, and practiced, leads to hell, the animal realm, or the ghost realm.

an8.40:8.2.pli: Yo sabbalahuso surāmerayapānassa vipāko, manussabhūtassa ummattakasaṃvattaniko hotī”ti.
an8.40:8.2.eng: The minimum result it leads to for a human being is madness.”
